thread.title: Who is winning the Apple presidential primary?
thread.title_full: Who is winning the Apple presidential primary?

title: Who is winning the Apple presidential primary?
text:
Tech giant once delivered a gusher of cash to Obama. So far for 2016, just a yawn. New models of the Apple watch in an Apple store in New York on Sept. 10, 2015. (Photo: Spencer Platt, Getty Images)
14 CONNECT 46 TWEET 1 LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE After Wednesday's letdown debut of new Apple products, attention turned right back to our fiasco of a presidential primary featuring a host of candidates as disappointing as the iPhone 6S .
While Bernie Sanders tries to convince America that if we just stuck with the iPhone 4, everybody could have Apple equality, Donald Trump promises a world where America is "Great Again" and we'll be able to skip iPhones 7 and 8 and go straight to the 9 from a time when Apple has "Great" new ideas "Again."
Like all political promises, neither is a likely scenario. But while politicians don't have much to say about the future of technology, technology firms do have a lot to say about the future of politicians.
ONPOLITICS
USA TODAY GOP Power Rankings, Week 2: Fiorina on fire
In 2008, Sen. Barack Obama won the support of Apple employees in the unofficial "Apple primary," a race to get the most donations from the company's well-paid staff. Six-figure support helped power his victory over Hillary Clinton and then John McCain.
So with more than 20 presidential candidates in the hunt, who has backing from Cupertino, Calif.?
Nobody really.
Apple employees have barely given presidential candidates enough to buy a top of the line iWatch, according to the Federal Election Commission's database of donations.
Who comes out on top?
Hillary Clinton: $14,450
Bernie Sanders: $2,492
Rand Paul: $500
Ben Carson: $250 Jenna Adamson is a USA TODAY Collegiate Network fellow.
14 CONNECT 46 TWEET 1 LINKEDIN 1 //usat.ly/1EZyCtB TOP VIDEOS
